abstract.text: Learn about time handling in host apps and plug-ins.

legalNotices.copyright: Copyright © 2025 Apple Inc. All rights reserved.

inlineContent.text: FxPlug 4 uses rational time of
doc://com.apple.documentation/documentation/coremedia/cmtime-u58
type to handle all timing in the host apps and plug-ins. Time can be in the form of a specific time or duration in an effect, object, or timeline (project). When FxPlug methods use
or
, that time generally refers to the current time that the host is providing or requesting.
provides methods to access other time values available in the host app. For FxPlug methods that don’t provide time, you can use
’s
to determine current playhead time in the project.

In Motion projects, timelines always start at zero, regardless of the custom timecode the user may set in the project’s properties. Input time is also always relative to the timeline start time. Other times of significance are indicated in the following figure.
In Final Cut Pro, projects can start at any timecode set by the user, and their timeline time will be continuous from that start time. Timeline time is independent of Input Time in Final Cut Pro, so
provides two convenience methods to convert between them:
and
. The following figure shows various times in the FxTiming API.

Although the timeline’s start time is set by the user, the timecode of the timeline will not necessarily correspond to the rational time your plug-in uses. This difference may be due to drop-frame timecode, or because the timecode resets to
. For example, if the user sets the project start timecode to
, the rational start time of the timeline when converted to seconds may be
seconds, but will NOT reset to
seconds when the timeline’s timecode reaches
You must
to use it in a Final Cut Pro project. You may notice significant differences in how
, and
return time values. To understand these differences, imagine that an effect template added to a clip in Final Cut Pro is equivalent to a complete timeline in Motion. For example, in Motion,

will return the plug-in effect’s start time relative to the Motion timeline. In Final Cut Pro, the same method will return the start time of the plug-in effect, relative to the native start time of the clip to which the user applies the template, regardless of the how much of the clip’s head has been trimmed by the user.

Effect templates that you apply to clips or other objects in Final Cut Pro may stretch to match the duration of the clip. When clips with effect templates are retimed by the user in Final Cut Pro, the effect template will adjust proportionally.
Unlike in Motion,
and

always return the native frame or sample durations of the clip, regardless of how fast or slow you retime it. If your plug-in attempts to determine the frame duration or frames per second of the timeline, then use
and
to make that calculation, as shown in the example below.

abstract.text: Use the FxPlug analysis API to analyze frames of source media before rendering them.
Create custom effects plug-ins for Final Cut Pro and Motion.
Use the scheduling APIs in FxPlug to retrieve frames from different times.
Exchange data with Final Cut Pro, and create effects plug-ins for Final Cut Pro and Motion.
A protocol that host applications implement to provide information to plug-ins that support the FxAnalyzer protocol.
A protocol that host applications implement to provide information to plug-ins that support the FxAnalyzer protocol.
A protocol you implement in your plug-in to analyze frames that the plug-in is applied to.
Defines the methods the host application provides to support a custom parameter view.
Returns the current time, expressed as a rational time.
A collection of methods for manipulating the keyframes of your FxPlug 4 plug-in.
A protocol that defines the methods provided by the host, so that a plug-in can query the timing properties of its input.
Provides the duration time for the effect.
Provides the native frame duration of the object to which the effect is applied.
Converts from timeline time to time of the filter’s image input.
Provides the native sample duration of the object to which the effect is applied.
Provides the start time for the effect.
Provides the start time of the filter’s image input clip.
The denominator of the timeline’s frame rate where the user applies the effect.
The numerator of the timeline’s frame rate where the user applies the effect.
Converts from input time of the filter’s image input to timeline time.
